title: 110_hr3003
content: Section 1 introduces nonrecognition of gain on qualified sales of telecommunications businesses under a new part in the Internal Revenue Code. This provision allows for the exclusion of gain on certain sales of telecommunications businesses. For qualified telecommunications sales, taxpayers can elect to treat them as involuntary property conversions under section 1033. The deferred gain on such sales cannot exceed $50,000,000. A qualified telecommunications sale refers to selling assets of a telecommunications business to a qualified business or selling stock in a corporation where the qualified business controls the corporation and its assets. For qualified telecommunications sales, taxpayers can elect to treat them as involuntary property conversions under section 1033. The deferred gain on such sales cannot exceed $50,000,000. A qualified telecommunications sale refers to selling assets of a telecommunications business to a qualified business or selling stock in a corporation where the qualified business controls the corporation and its assets. A qualified business is defined as a person owning 10 or fewer broadcast stations with a fair market value equal to or greater. An interest in a broadcast station is considered qualified if it represents 50 percent or more of the total net assets of the entity. For telecommunications sales, certain criteria must be met for individuals, partnerships, or corporations to qualify based on net assets and average after-tax income. The rules for determining a qualified business in telecommunications sales include limitations on the number of prior purchases and specific criteria for net assets and after-tax income. The term 'income' refers to taxable income reduced by the net income tax for the year, with rules for determining average after-tax income. All persons treated as a single employer are considered one person for this subsection. 'Telecommunications business' is defined as any business providing communication services by wire. The term 'telecommunications business' refers to any business providing communication services by wire, cable, radio, satellite, or other technology governed by the Communications Act of 1934 or the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Special rules apply to stock of a corporation operating a telecommunications business in a qualified telecommunications sale. If gain would be recognized on a sale due to subsection (b), the taxpayer can elect to reduce the basis of depreciable property held immediately after the sale. The reduction amount is determined by the Secretary's regulations. For property acquired in an involuntary conversion, refer to section 1033(b). If a telecommunications business is resold within 5 years, there is a recapture of tax benefits. If a qualified telecommunications sale results in a recapture event within 5 years, the purchaser's tax will increase by 20 percent of the consideration or the dollar limitation. An exception applies if the taxpayer reinvests in another qualified sale within 60 days. The term 'recapture event' in a qualified telecommunications sale refers to any sale or disposition of assets or stock acquired in the initial sale, or in the case of subsection (c)(2), any sale of a telecommunications business or transaction resulting in loss of control. The term 'recapture event' in a qualified telecommunications sale refers to any sale or disposition of assets or stock acquired in the initial sale, or in the case of subsection (c)(2), any sale of a telecommunications business or transaction resulting in loss of control. The term shall not include any sale or other disposition resulting from the default, or imminent default, of any indebtedness of the taxpayer. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts for subchapter O of chapter 1 of the Code. Part V. Certain Sales of Telecommunications Businesses. The amendments made by this section apply to sales in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Loan guarantee program to encourage diversity of ownership of telecommunications businesses. The Small Business Administration can guarantee loans for qualified businesses purchasing assets or stock related to telecommunications sales. Limitations include requiring security with a first lien position, a maximum guarantee of 95% of the outstanding balance, and fees for loans repayable in more than 1 year. The Small Business Administration can collect a guarantee fee for loans not repayable in 1 year, and may charge the borrower. The Administrator will not guarantee a loan unless the borrower forfeits their FCC license upon default. The Administrator has the authority to enter contracts for services and agreements with other entities. The Small Business Administration can enter agreements with other Federal agencies and issue regulations related to default, foreclosure procedures, and other relevant matters. The Administrator is defined as the Administrator of the Small Business Administration, and a "qualified business" is defined as per section 1071(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Appropriations are authorized as necessary for the implementation of this section.
